title: CTRL0000916062 - Transcribed Interview of Stephen Ayres, (June 22, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 12:00 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
Let's go on the record at noon.
This is the continuation of a transcribed interview of
Mr. Stephen Ayres that's being conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate
the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol, pursuant to House Resolution 503.
We conducted the first part of the interview on Friday, June 17th.
Present for the interview today, we have myself,
have Mr. Stephen Ayres and his counsel, Mr. Eugene Ohm.
Would you like to put anything on the record, Mr. Ohm?
So, Mr. Ayres, we just wanted to ask you a few followup questions
specific to some of the statements that we saw on your filings just to see where you are
and what your feelings are about it today.
One question I did have that I failed to ask last week regarding January 6th
specifically, do you recall people protesting at the Department of Justice building that
sure where that building is at myself.
No, I don't remember hearing anything or seeing anything.
So you don't remember even like walking by it or seeing anything at
If I did, I wouldn't have known what --1 don't think I would've known what
building it was because I don't remember -- I don't remember hearing or seeing anything
about that -- the DOJ building itself.
We also looked at the video that was in your criminal complaint.
By the way, just letting you know, so we are also joined by
who is our deputy com ms director for the committee; and
who is also an investigative counsel for the committee.
It was mentioned in the affidavit in support of
Do you know what video I'm talking about?
When did you all record that video?
Yeah, that was like right after we got back to the hotel, like, literally like
And, in the video, it's Mr. Matthew Perna and a friend; I believe her name is
I believe it was right after January 6th?
We just -- that was one of Matthew's friends.
ran into her up at the Capitol literally like a half-hour before we walked back to the hotel
I didn't know her up until that point right there.
So Mr. Perna was the connection with her and you all --
-- kind of being in the room together for that video?
So the video is titled "It was all antifa breaking into the Capitol on
I guess the question that just naturally arises is, do you believe today that
That wasn't really my -- I didn't even want to do the video to
We posted it on my account.
I don't know if his account was already shut down or whatever the case
For whatever reason, I can't remember
That was basically, he wanted to get it up and going right then and there.
I personally was just agreeing with everything he said because he was kind of
seeing like antifa there or anything like that.
basically agreeing with, you know, his statements.
I don't know if you could tell.
I was just kind of going along and just
So, sitting here in June of 2022, who do you think was responsible for
Oh, I definitely believe, you know, it was the Trump supporters, you know.
Not all of them were there to be bad and cause problems and drama, but definitely there
was, you know, definitely was some troublemakers in the mix that definitely got it all
I think there's a handful of people that got it started, and it just got out of
And you include yourself in the group of Trump supporters that
went in the Capitol that day?
Also in the video, it's discussed that the police let you all into the Capitol.
So, just another followup question, do you believe that it was the police that let the
rioters into the Capitol on January 6th?
When I got down there, the place was already overrun.
we went in through that door there was no -- I believe from where I could -- where I was
seeing, there was -- I don't think there was any officers there.
themselves, and I think some people were breaking the windows right there as well.
But then, once we got in
So they basically pushed through and got through the door
Because you came in through the Senate door, so there was like a
Yeah, I think there was some broken windows there.
And then that door, that door right there, they pushed through.
And I think I touched on this a little bit on Friday, but I just want to go back
You recall seeing violence as you were walking to the Capitol and approaching the
When we were down on the ground, like the actual the ground level
before you start going up any steps there, I remember seeing up in the far -- it would've
been my far right corner up above the, you know, the scaffolding, and they had the whole
setup for the inauguration, I remember seeing skirmishes up on that far right corner
when I first got there with -- you know, they were -- police were using tear gas and stuff
And, I guess, what made you continue walking towards the Capitol?
us understand why you still continued even though you witnessed what you saw.
I think it was just everybody was pushing through.
there was a bunch of people that had bullhorns kind of like directing traffic, and just -- we
were just kind of going with the flow.
And everything -- you know, if you're going that way, you're kind of stuck going that way
You kind of got packed in like sardines right there.
One of the witnesses in the affidavit is cited as saying like you were
screaming and yelling, I guess, on your live stream inside the Capitol.
No, I wasn't screaming and yelling.
I think that was the people around me;
there was a lot of screaming and yelling.
awe with my phone in my hand just showing what was taking place.
I was more standing there like in shock and
I guess, looking back to -- just help summarize it for me.
back on you going in the Capitol, how would you describe that experience, and how
would you feel about your actions looking back on that day?
Me, personally, I'm embarrassed, you know, from the whole situation.
I didn't realize, you know, when -- it took me for about a year before I realized just how
bad it was, before it like sat in.
actually was until I saw one of the documentaries that were put out on like Netflix or on
TV or HBO or something, that I actually sat and watched the whole thing, and it kind of
like all sunk in just how bad it really was.
And I even told my attorney, I didn't realize how bad it
Because like, even up to that point, even after like the year, I was like, man,
they're really blowing this thing out of proportion.
But then, when I sat and watched
that documentary -- I'm not sure whose it was, who put it out -- but that's when I -- really
I was like, you know, that was pretty bad, you know.
And that's -- you know, like I'm embarrassed about it, you know.
I'm --you know, I was -- when I was younger, I had problems with, you know, drugs and
alcohol, and I finally got my name cleared up, and I've been doing good for so long, and
it's like, you know, I had -- then I get in this trouble.
embarrassing, shameful and, you know, kind of disgusting at the same time, you know --
It's just like, for me, it was
We also touched on this a little bit Friday, but I want to ask it more directly,
So, looking back to the -- you said the weeks before January 6th when you made
-- what inspired you to actually travel to Washington, D.C., and attend the
Me, personally, you know, I had in my head at the time that, you know, with
everything the President was putting out, President Trump was putting out, the election
was rigged, and, you know, the votes were wrong and stuff, you know.
social media a lot back then, you know, I'm talking hours a day.
head and eventually, you know, got into my head and being in my head, oh, you know, it's
down there and, you know, show up basically.
The President is calling on us to come.
I think it just got into my
You know, we need to get
So I know it was like the messages on social media, but President Trump,
was that kind of the singular person that was inspiring you to come or --
Yeah, oh, for sure, for sure, because I probably wouldn't have -- you know, I
wanted to see one of his rallies, and that's like one of the reasons I went down there, but
him saying you must be there, get down there, be there, that's kind of like my thing of
like, you know, I need to make sure I'm down there.
After the election, even today, right, so President Trump is still making
claims that the 2020 election was stolen.
today about the election being stolen?
I guess, for you, Mr. Ayres, what is your view
Honestly, you know, after seeing some of the evidence, you know, all of his
filings, all the filings being put in, they're all one after another being shot down, you
know, saying there's no evidence, there's nothing to support this, and, you know, I kind of
feel like maybe I got caught up in all of it with, you know, the social media and everything.
Now, you know -- you know, I think that's all it really was because I don't feel the
caught up with the social media and the news and over -- you know, basically overtaken
of like, all right, maybe I was a little clouded, kind of a little clouded judgment on the
And now that I'm outside of it and I could sit back and look at it all, it's kind
So is it fair for me to say that you don't believe the election was
I think I was all caught up in the -- all the hype on the social media.
I think it just really got to me, honestly.
I'm the complete opposite, you know.
When -- and just to follow up on that, you said when you kind of got outside
When did you get outside, and I guess how did you -- how did you get
yourself where you were outside and able to start kind of considering things
I think, once I started getting away from the social media, all within
like -- like I said, about the year -- I'd say right around the year mark is when I'm like, you
know, I started looking around, started reading up on stuff because I like to research
everything, and I'm just like everything that he -- him and his attorneys put in just kept
I'm like, you know, if there was any evidence or prudence to the whole thing,
someone would've taken the case on, like, okay, we have something we could hear, we
have something we could see, but everything was being shot down, you know.
basically like where I kind of felt like, okay, maybe it was just a big sham and a bunch of,
you know, stories being pushed on social media.
you're talking about the decision to travel to D.C. for January 6th, and then, in thinking
about your experience that day, did you think at any point during the day that your
presence or something you would do on that day would make a difference to help
I think just being there and like showing support was supposed to -- kind of
how I felt like, you know, my President called on me; I'm here, you know what I'm saying.
That's kind of how I -- I feel like how I took it.
could've made a change or made a difference, but I felt like as a collective, if I was there,
you know, I'm another person there to show some support.
I don't think I, per se, myself individually
And it sounds like your, you know, being on social
media and seeing all of that affected your perception of this.
curious if you could remember what you might have thought about what the importance
of having so many people there on January 6th might have been.
You know, like if you can -- maybe a different way to ask this is, putting yourself
back in your shoes that morning when you're going there to the rally, like what did you
think the best-case scenario was going to be having all these people in -- on January 6th in
I thought it was just showing support because, you know, Trump kept saying
there's a big reveal coming and this and that.
So I thought maybe they were going to
say, hey, the election, you know, is getting turned around or, you know, Vice President
Pence was not, you know -- I'm not sure how to say it -- you know, agreeing with the
something big coming, and that's kind of like why I felt like maybe I needed to be down
I thought, you know, he made it seem like there was
And then, if you could remember, as that morning progressed into the
afternoon and you made your way down to the Capitol and ultimately ended up inside
the building, do you remember having any thoughts as that was happening about what
I don't know if it's me.
Am I lag -- am I lagging?
So I'm curious if -- my question was, on the day of, as that progressed from
the rally towards people walking down the Capitol and ultimately you go in the building,
do you remember -- remember thinking what the purpose of that was, what was the
purpose of going into the Capitol?
You broke up a little bit in the beginning, but I think I heard it all.
I was just following the crowd really.
think I really had a purpose.
had -- I don't think there was -- I didn't personally think there was going to make a
I was just basically following the crowd and, you know, trying to walk
I just was like I wanted to walk through.
So this is a good followup that I -- so basically, you're talking about following
I guess, why did you go to the Capitol and march towards the Capitol after
President Trump's speech in the first place?
I'm sorry; you were breaking up again.
I'm not sure if I'm having connection issues or if --
Let's recess in place real quick.
We'll go back on the record.
Mr. Ayres, I guess, what led you to actually go to the Capitol?
caused you to leave the Ellipse and walk towards the Capitol?
Oh, I was -- I basically walked down there after Trump said, let's walk, you
know -- everybody head over to the Capitol and show your support or, you know, your
disdain or however he put it.
know, basically, you know, he said let's -- when the rally is over, let's head over down to
the Capitol and show your support for me, or however he put it.
That's basically why I walked over there, is I was just, you
Were you tracking the Capitol even being an event until President Trump
Were you even tracking that the Capitol would be an event until
President Trump said it in his speech?
Yeah, I wasn't planning on walking down there until I heard that.
around for 10, 15 minutes afterwards, maybe even a little bit longer, talking and stuff
before we even headed down there.
having plans on heading down there prior to that -- to him saying:
But I don't -- we -- I do not recall ever talking about
Do you remember how or what route you walked to get to the Capitol?
I didn't hear that last question thoroughly.
Do you remember the route you took to get to the Capitol?
I'm not sure what exact road it was.
Everyone that was sitting in front of the stage, there's a
road right there where the security detail started, that road that led -- we took that road
And then, also, we talked about this a little bit last week, can you
describe again President Trump's 4:17 message to go home, what you recall about that?
The video where he told people to go home, do you remember that message?
I kind of caught pieces of that.
I think you said describe Trump's 4:17 message to go home?
And, Mr. -- I don't know if this is going to mess things up, but, you
know, you can do the closed captioning thing.
There's a cc on the bottom, and I think
maybe if you can't hear us, then if you could read it.
On mine, it's right to the left of the mute button.
Another option is for us to --
It's on the bottom left-hand corner.
Oh, I see it on bottom left corner.
So you can use your phone in addition to video if there are
I got the closed captions on now, it looks like.
So my question was, do you remember President Trump's
4:17 message telling the rioters to go home, and if you do, what was your reaction to that
When we heard it, that's basically when, you know, we started
We -- you know, we were hanging around watching at that time,
but I remember people started bringing it up, and then that's when we actually left.
When we saw his tweet and we heard about his tweet, that's when we actually decided
Was it a group of people that were discussing this video around you?
I remember hearing it because there was so many people everywhere.
it's like when something got out, it got out and spread very fast because everybody was
kind of on social media watching that as well.
But I remember hearing about it, and it
seemed like it started to clear out pretty good.
Once that come out, it seemed as
though it started to clear out pretty good.
Do you remember where you were on the Capitol when
I was down on the very end.
So the door that we went in, if you're
looking at that door on, you said -- I believe you said it was the Senate wing --
-- instead of -- if we would've took a left and went around the side of the
building right there, we were standing right on that end down over there where -- the
The west side of the Capitol.
And then I just want to ask you kind of an overarching question.
this is a tough summary, but sitting here today, right, what are your views about
President Trump and any -- anything that he may have had to do with January 6th and
what happened at the Capitol Building?
Me, personally, I'm upset with the whole thing because I basically feel like I
was used like a pawn in a chess match or something.
used to basically do his dirty work, you know.
He got everybody all hyped up at the rally
itself, and then he kind of like sent everybody on their way, you know.
feel like I was used in the situation, and, you know, I don't feel happy about it.
Do you think President Trump could've done anything before the 4:17 tweet
message to maybe diffuse the situation?
I think I said it previously, I wish he would've come out
like at 1:30, because they said the stuff at the Capitol kind of started around 1 or a little
bit before 1, if I remember what I've seen on the news if that's correct or not.
By time we got down there, you know -- if we stood around for 15, 20 minutes, by
the time we walked down there -- it took 10, 15 minutes -- by 1:30, 1:35, when we got
there, the place was completely overrun at that point, I believe.
opinion, he should have -- as soon as he saw that taking place, he should have come out
protest, but this is not what we're about.
Look, this is not what we're about.
Yeah, we're here to rally and peacefully
I wish he would've come out sooner and said, "Hey, guys, look, this is not -- we're
not here for this, you know," and said, you know, send people on their way or stand there
Three hours later or 4 hours later, whatever it ends up being, 3 and a half, you know,
that's -- a lot of damage got done in that, you know, 3, 3 and-a-half hour window.
I wish he would've come out and done something like that.
I want to go back to something I touched on last week, but -- I just want to
make sure we're clear, do you remember President Trump's December 19th tweet about
I wouldn't be able to remember it offhand unless I like seen it or something,
or like I could look back through my phone and stuff, but I don't even have those accounts
So I don't remember like exactly right now.
Another thing I meant to ask -- I actually didn't ask you this on Friday, I
meant to ask it though, do you consider your -- did you consider yourself in this time as
like a follower of QAnon or anything like that?
I didn't follow it like hard core like some people did.
was looking at some of it, and I was watching it and trying to see if any of it would
the same time, it was kind of interesting.
But I wasn't like 100 percent on it.
I was kind of like on the fence.
You know, it seems a little farfetched, but at
I was like 50/50 on the fence and seeing if any
of that stuff was actually happening, which like a lot -- 99.9 percent of the time, nothing
ever happened from what they said anyway.
So you kind of touched on this.
Oh, I think it -- you know, excuse me language, I think it's total BS now, you
know, after seeing it, you know.
whatever they want to call it, I don't know.
What are your views about QAnon
I know you kind of touched at end of your answer, but what are -- what are
So, you know, I was watching it, but I
I don't see none of the stuff that ever -- was said in
So, you know, I think it's nothing but, you know, hearsay or
Before I move on to another -- a different topic completely, I want to make
sure no one else on the call has any followup questions?
Yeah, I just have one quick question.
You talked about your views of
President Trump and what you wish he had done differently.
accepting responsibility for what you have done individually, and I can appreciate that
and how important that is for you to move on.
about sort of how you balance those two things, about what your individual responsibility
versus what you wish leadership had done that might have prevented this, if you've
I'm curious if you have thought at all
You know, I, myself, like I said earlier, I'm embarrassed over the
whole situation, you know, but at the same -- you know, at the same time, I was
provoking it too, I feel like, you know, with the social -- my social media posts leading up
off of TV and YouTube channels and stuff.
you know, at the same time, it makes me mad that I let myself get so deep into it that I
couldn't realize or see what I -- what I was actually doing, you know.
You know, I was on there basically just copying stuff I was seeing and hearing
So I probably hyped up a lot of stuff too, and,
I consider myself to be fairly intelligent, and it makes me mad that I let myself get
so deep and so, you know, indulging into it when I should have took a step back and say,
look, I really need to open my eyes and look at this stuff, you know.
feel like I kind of was just following the pack, man, like basically following the pack, you
And I think that there's -- obviously
there's a lot of people who fall into that boat too, you know.
So, again, Mr. Perna -- I -- look, we understand that -- Mr. Ayres, that
Mr. Perna took his life early in February.
I'm sorry if I said Mr. Perna.
I was thinking about Mr. Perna when I said that.
And I just wanted to ask
you a few followup questions about that event.
So we are tracking the website
Are you familiar with that website?
I -- I didn't know about it until when I was talking to my attorney.
So that website, like others that -- like in other statements
we've seen where Mr. Perna's family is kind of, you know, advocating about the justice
system and other things that Mr. Perna was struggling with.
views overall about what the family's statements have been since his death?
They say you go through all the emotions.
I'm sad from the situation, and usually every time his name gets brought up,
I mean, those are their views.
I mean, obviously, they're probably very
You know, when you go through grief, you go through a lot of different
I, personally, I just stand back,
But I don't know -- I can't speak for them and, you know, how they
I just -- you know, it's a sad situation, so I can't imagine what they're going
And, look, I understand, and like I said last -- on Friday, I
know it's very difficult for you to talk about.
Like it's reasonably your friend, right, who
-- passed away, so that's why I'm -- look, I try to bring this up as sparingly as
possible, but I do appreciate your candor in answering these questions about Mr. Perna,
because I know it can be tough.
And the last question I wanted to ask you about that is, let's say you were to
be -- have a more public statement about January 6th.
I guess, what do you think
Mr. Perna's family, to the best of what you know about them, what they might say or how
His aunt -- his aunt is pretty, you know, pretty fiery.
She's a good lady, but she's pretty fiery.
respond or feel or, you know.
I'm not sure how, you know, she would
So it's really that Ms. Geri, I believe, is that her name?
So that's the main individual that you kind of think of who might actually
speak out or something if you were to have a more public-facing testimony of some sort?
Yeah, because she's -- I believe she's been on a couple
shows already, you know, talking and stuff, so she's kind of -- I think she's kind of like
the -- she's kind of like the one spearheading the, you know, website and stuff and
And, from what I've seen, it seems like her grievances are mostly with the
I think that's kind of how I was taking it too.
I've talked to her a couple times since all this, so I -- you know, but from what I've seen on
TV and, you know, the shows that she's been on and whatnot, it kind of seems that way.
Does that trigger any followup from any other counsel or
Any other questions in general that I might not have touched on?
Thank you so much for being here.
that happened on January 6th and what you've learned since, you know, if Donald Trump
ran for President in 2024, do you think you would support him?
But I'm just curious for your personal opinion, you know, given everything
Honestly, I -- I don't even -- I don't -- I couldn't say yes; I couldn't say no.
Right now, where I feel, like right now at this moment, I would say probably not because
I'm kind of upset with, you know, the way he kind of handled the situation.
I'm an adult; I take my full responsibility.
that type of control and that type of following from people, I feel like you should
definitely be more careful with your words and the things you do and say and post
because a lot of people are looking to you and following you.
But, when you have that type of power and
Right now I would say, no, I wouldn't.
If there's no other questions, Mr. Ayres, again, I just want to say
thank you -- i f I might, I apologize.
Mr. Ayres, nice to meet you.
And, Gene, it's been some years, but it's good to see you too.
So, picking up on where you left off, Mr. Ayres, on talking about the words that
the President used, you said earlier today that, at the rally, that he was getting people
Do you remember what in particular, the types of things he was saying, that
was having people have that reaction?
I think it was basically just the same stuff that he was just repeating on line,
Everything that he said on line he basically covered in that rally as well, you
know -- you know, the election was taken, and, you know, the votes weren't right here,
he was putting out he basically covered in that rally, if I believe -- from what I can
didn't already know or heard him say prior to that rally.
It was just like a little bit of everything.
It didn't seem like there was anything new that I heard from him that I
One of the things that at least was new was his public statements
President in the day or two before and particularly that morning of the rally and directing
people's attention to the Vice President and what he could do.
You know, he had started tweeting about the Vice
Yeah, I remember seeing that stuff because I think he was saying
that he was part of the deep state or -- or I don't know, maybe I'm
making -- hearing -- not hearing it correctly, but I remember hearing stuff about him.
did get pretty -- you know, start talking about him quite a bit prior to the rally as well, you
And what was your feeling about Mike Pence that day and hearing the
President talk about him and then also walking towards the Capitol where he was
Once we started hearing about -- when we were walking down there is when
they were saying that -- if I remember correctly, we were walking down there, and people
had like radios playing of what was being said into the Capitol and stuff, and they were
saying he ain't -- he's not doing what he was gonna -- supposed to do or this or that.
remember it getting a lot of people mad from that.
amongst people, you know, him highlighting Vice President Pence that way.
And it certainly seemed like the focus of that anger trained on Pence by that
I think it just caused more anger
point, in terms of that was the man that people were thinking about, at least is what you
were hearing as you were going toward the Capitol.
On my way walking down there, I remember
hearing people hollering, you know, obscenities and whatnot about Mike Pence on the
So they were already fired up as we were getting down there.
Had you ever seen that anger towards Vice President Pence before
No, huh-uh, I don't recall, you know.
I thought everybody was kind of like
on his side up until all that -- you know, until, you know, President Trump started going
his way or putting the words out there towards him.
There are a lot -- thousands of people who did not go in the Capitol, who
walked down to the building, stayed around the building, even stayed on the outside
close to but didn't go in.
you help us better understand why you kept making your way towards the building?
And so I understand that you were part of a large crowd.
Me, personally, like I just wanted to walk through.
plain Jane as that sounds, I just wanted to -- that was my thinking.
I didn't care about, you know, the Vice President being in there or any of those
I just wanted to walk through.
And then, once we got up top towards where we actually went in, me and Matt
kept getting separated, so we kept finding each other, losing each other, finding each
And I was just standing out there.
Next thing you know, I see
I'm like, oh, they're letting people in, so I started
I didn't know at that time that they pushed through at that time.
I wasn't sure at the time then.
So certainly we have a lot of footage from that day from a lot of people who
you hearing people say that folks were actually going into the Capitol itself before you
And, as you approached the building, and it's a mile and a half, were
I thought they were already in the building by the time we got
I thought people were going through by the time we were already getting up
And so, while I understand that you were part of a crowd, it
sounds like you made the choice at the time to keep going because you had heard people
were going in and you wanted to get up close and see if you could do that yourself?
And, in terms of thinking that they were letting people in, I think
went over it earlier, but no officer ever said or waved you into the building
It's just you didn't get any opposition as you moved up.
Yeah, I didn't see -- I didn't see anybody like say "hey,
come on over this way" or nothing like that.
like literally say "you can come in" or nothing like that.
didn't strike you as serious about that day?
And then like I said, I didn't see any officers
Now, the media coverage of the -- of that day was immediate and
By the time I got down there, all the
And I know you said earlier today that it took about a year for you to realize
I mean, what about what you had been seeing right after the fact
I'm not sure if maybe I was just a little bit -- I'm not sure if I -- if my brain
getting in the way of it, you know.
Even some of the stuff I saw, you know, I seen some
people fighting with the cops there at one of the doors while I was standing back just
watching and recording and stuff, but -- I've seen it, but it's like it didn't set in or
